prompt: What is the relationship between F(p) and O(¬p)?
options: F(p) implies O(¬p) but not vice versa
hint: Forbidden means obligated not to do.
explanation: F(p) ≡ O(¬p): Something being forbidden is equivalent to its negation being obligatory. If lying is forbidden, then not-lying is obligatory. Similarly, P(p) ≡ ¬O(¬p): permission is absence of obligation to the contrary.
visual_concept: Forbidden = must not. Obligatory = must. So forbidden(p) = must(not-p). Different words, same logical content.
